author: gcolvin
content: I likely missed it, but what happens if miners aren't trying to "burn the city down" but enough of them decide to keep on mining the PoW chain and enough exchanges go along, for some value of "enough."  Does this endanger the merge, or just cause the sort of chain split that has always been our ultimate governance backstop?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dannyryan> Yeah, ultimately a community can choose to run a pow version of the chain with same prehistory up to the merge. Assuming a successful merge and a successful pow fork, they would just both exist in isolation post merge. No danger to the actual protocol. Unquantifiable risk to "brand" or other soft features
In my estimation, the application layer will not do so well in a minority fork. E.g. unsupported oracles, defi collateral price collapses having ripple effects, etc
Also, difficultly bomb may or may not come into play on pow fork viability

author: gcolvin
content: Thanks <@!826829234685214772> Danny.  That puts my concerns to rest.
